@echuawu With this change, redeploying one testbed will break other testbeds on same server. To stop bleeding, we have reverted it.
@wangxin, could you provide more details of the phenomenon you met? There was a check that if it's a shared server, the reinstall of 8021q module would be skipped.

@echuawu The check in this PR assumes that there will be two or more docker containers with the name `docker-ngts`. However, that is not always the case; there could be no containers with this name. (Additionally, I don't know what container that's referring to.)

For instance, for testing with a KVM image, I can have a t0 and t1-lag topo running simultaneously on the same machine. There will not be any container with the name `docker-ngts` running here. If I remove the t1-lag topo, then this code will then remove the `8021q` kernel module, which will then remove all VLANs created, breaking t0 topo traffic.

Hi @saiarcot895 , currently, this PR works fine at our testbed, and it really improve the deploy passing rate. There is no reason to revert the PR directly. Could you add some check condition according to your specific case?
Please don't do cherry-pick of this PR.

@echuawu Sorry for the delay here, but I think the approach of this PR is too heavy-handed. Specifically, removing the 802.1q module makes the assumption that the server does not use VLANs at all (even if there's only one container running on the system, VLANs could be used for other purposes). Removing and re-inserting a kernel module that affects networking on a server is risky at best.

> @echuawu Sorry for the delay here, but I think the approach of this PR is too heavy-handed. Specifically, removing the 802.1q module makes the assumption that the server does not use VLANs at all (even if there's only one container running on the system, VLANs could be used for other purposes). We should have a assessment about the benefits it gained and the potential risky as you mentioned it may leads to. @bingwang-ms , what's your ideas?
